title: 1 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who came out of Judah by the word of the LORD unto Bethel in 1 Kings 13?
options: A man of God
King Jeroboam
An old prophet
An angel
questions.correctAnswer: A man of God
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:1 states that a man of God came out of Judah by the word of the LORD unto Bethel.

questions.question: What did the man of God cry against in Bethel?
options: The altar
The king
The temple
The high priest
questions.correctAnswer: The altar
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:2 says the man of God cried against the altar in the word of the LORD.

questions.question: What was the name of the child that the LORD said would be born unto the house of David?
options: Josiah
Jeroboam
Samuel
David
questions.correctAnswer: Josiah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:2 mentions the child Josiah by name who shall be born unto the house of David.

questions.question: What sign did the man of God give to show the LORD’s word was true?
options: The altar shall be rent
The king’s hand will be healed
A lion will appear
The skies will darken
questions.correctAnswer: The altar shall be rent
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:3 states the sign was the altar being rent and the ashes poured out.

questions.question: What happened to Jeroboam’s hand when he tried to seize the man of God?
options: It dried up and he could not pull it back
It was healed instantly
It became strong
It was covered with leprosy
questions.correctAnswer: It dried up and he could not pull it back
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:4 says Jeroboam’s hand dried up so he could not pull it in again.

questions.question: Did the altar break and pour out ashes as the man of God said it would?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:5 confirms the altar was rent and ashes poured out as the sign spoken by the man of God.

questions.question: What did the king ask the man of God to do after his hand was restored?
options: Come home with me and refresh thyself
Leave the city immediately
Pray for the priests
Build a new altar
questions.correctAnswer: Come home with me and refresh thyself
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:7 records the king inviting the man of God to come home and refresh himself.

questions.question: What was the man of God’s command from the LORD regarding eating and drinking in Bethel?
options: Eat no bread nor drink water
Eat only bread but no water
Drink water but no bread
Eat and drink as you please
questions.correctAnswer: Eat no bread nor drink water
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:9 commands the man of God not to eat bread nor drink water in that place.

questions.question: True or False: The man of God obeyed the LORD’s command and returned by the same way he came to Bethel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:10 states he went another way and did not return by the same way he came.

questions.question: Who lied to the man of God to bring him back to eat bread and drink water?
options: An old prophet in Bethel
King Jeroboam
A priest from Judah
An angel
questions.correctAnswer: An old prophet in Bethel
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:18 reveals the old prophet lied to the man of God to bring him back.

questions.question: What happened to the man of God after he disobeyed the LORD’s command and ate bread?
options: He was killed by a lion
He was blessed with long life
He became king
He was healed of sickness
questions.correctAnswer: He was killed by a lion
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:24 describes how a lion met him by the way and slew him as punishment for disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: The lion ate the man of God’s body after killing him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:28 states the lion had not eaten the carcase nor torn the ass.

questions.question: Who buried the man of God after his death?
options: The old prophet who brought him back
King Jeroboam
The priests of Bethel
The sons of the man of God
questions.correctAnswer: The old prophet who brought him back
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:29 shows the old prophet took up the carcase and buried him.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Kings 13:33: 'After this thing Jeroboam returned not from his ______ way.'
options: evil
righteous
narrow
straight
questions.correctAnswer: evil
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:33 says Jeroboam returned not from his evil way after these events.

questions.question: What became sin unto the house of Jeroboam according to 1 Kings 13:34?
options: Cutting it off and destroying it from the face of the earth
Building new altars
Praying to the LORD
Feeding the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Cutting it off and destroying it from the face of the earth
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:34 states that the sin was to cut it off and destroy it from the face of the earth.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 13 teach us about obedience to God's Word when a man of God was commanded not to eat or drink in a certain place?
options: Obedience is essential even when others lie to you
You may disobey if someone claims an angel spoke to them
It is acceptable to eat and drink if you are hungry
You should follow the advice of others over God's command
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience is essential even when others lie to you
questions.explanation: The man of God was commanded not to eat or drink or return by the same way (1 Kings 13:9, 17), but he disobeyed because the old prophet lied to him (1 Kings 13:18-19). This shows the importance of obeying God's word regardless of others' claims (1 Kings 13:21-22).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to compromise in obedience. Based on 1 Kings 13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Disobedience to God's command leads to severe consequences
Compromise is acceptable if it benefits others
God will overlook small disobedience
Prayer can replace obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience to God's command leads to severe consequences
questions.explanation: The man of God disobeyed the LORD's command and ate bread and drank water, leading to his death by a lion (1 Kings 13:21-24). This demonstrates that disobedience has serious consequences (1 Kings 13:26-28).

questions.question: How does the passage emphasize prayer and intercession for others?
options: The man of God prayed for King Jeroboam's hand to be restored
Jeroboam refused to pray for the man of God
The prophet did not pray for anyone
Only priests are allowed to pray for kings
questions.correctAnswer: The man of God prayed for King Jeroboam's hand to be restored
questions.explanation: When Jeroboam's hand dried up after trying to seize the man of God, the man prayed to the LORD and the hand was restored (1 Kings 13:4-6). This shows the power and importance of intercessory prayer.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 13 illustrate the importance of spiritual discernment in fellowship and accepting invitations?
options: The man of God initially refused to eat with the old prophet because of God's command
He accepted the invitation without question
He ignored God's Word to maintain fellowship
He asked others for their opinion before deciding
questions.correctAnswer: The man of God initially refused to eat with the old prophet because of God's command
questions.explanation: The man of God refused the old prophet's invitation to eat bread and drink water because God commanded him not to (1 Kings 13:8-10, 16-17). This highlights the need for spiritual discernment in social and church life.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and honesty can be learned from the old prophet's actions in 1 Kings 13?
options: Lying about an angel's message led to the man of God's disobedience
Honesty was maintained throughout the story
Deception was justified to show kindness
The old prophet told the truth as commanded by God
questions.correctAnswer: Lying about an angel's message led to the man of God's disobedience
questions.explanation: The old prophet lied, claiming an angel told him to bring the man of God back to eat and drink, which was false (1 Kings 13:18-19). This caused the man of God to disobey God’s direct command, demonstrating the harm of dishonesty.

questions.question: How does this passage teach about the consequences of disobedience to God in family and leadership contexts?
options: Jeroboam's disobedience and leading others into sin caused his house to be cut off
Disobedience to God had no effect on Jeroboam's family
Only personal disobedience matters, not leadership actions
God rewards leaders regardless of their obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam's disobedience and leading others into sin caused his house to be cut off
questions.explanation: Jeroboam continued in evil ways and consecrated unworthy priests, which became sin unto his house and led to its destruction (1 Kings 13:33-34). This teaches the impact of leadership disobedience on family legacy.

questions.question: True or False: The man of God obeyed the LORD's command by not returning the same way or eating and drinking at Bethel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Although the man of God initially obeyed by taking another route (1 Kings 13:10), he ultimately disobeyed by eating and drinking at the old prophet's house after being deceived (1 Kings 13:19).

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 13 show the importance of trusting God's direct word over human advice?
options: The man of God was deceived by the old prophet's false claim and disobeyed God
Human advice is always more reliable than God's word
God's word is flexible depending on circumstances
The man of God trusted only the old prophet
questions.correctAnswer: The man of God was deceived by the old prophet's false claim and disobeyed God
questions.explanation: The man of God was commanded by the LORD not to eat or drink there, but trusted the old prophet’s lie instead (1 Kings 13:17-19). This teaches that God's word must be trusted above human counsel.

questions.question: How does the story of the lion that killed the disobedient man of God teach about perseverance through trials and consequences?
options: Disobedience can bring severe trials, but God's justice is certain
The lion was a metaphor for forgiveness
Trials are always avoided by the faithful
Consequences are only temporary
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience can bring severe trials, but God's justice is certain
questions.explanation: After disobeying God’s command, the man of God was killed by a lion as a direct consequence (1 Kings 13:24-26). This shows the certainty of God's judgment and the seriousness of obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The man of God was commanded not to ____ bread or drink water in the place he was sent to.
options: eat
buy
offer
sell
questions.correctAnswer: eat
questions.explanation: The LORD commanded the man of God not to eat bread or drink water in Bethel (1 Kings 13:9, 17), emphasizing strict obedience.

questions.question: True or False: After the man of God was killed, the old prophet buried him in his own grave and requested to be buried beside him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The old prophet took the man of God’s body, buried him in his own grave, and requested to be buried beside him because of the prophetic word against the altar (1 Kings 13:29-31).

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 13 demonstrate the value of faithful witness even amid opposition?
options: The man of God boldly proclaimed God's word against the altar despite King Jeroboam's presence
He avoided confrontation to stay safe
He only spoke to the king in private
He compromised to avoid trouble
questions.correctAnswer: The man of God boldly proclaimed God's word against the altar despite King Jeroboam's presence
questions.explanation: The man of God came from Judah and boldly cried against the altar at Bethel before King Jeroboam (1 Kings 13:1-2). This teaches courage in witnessing God's truth.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can we learn from King Jeroboam's reaction when his hand dried up?
options: Jeroboam humbled himself and asked the man of God to pray for him
Jeroboam ignored the warning and blamed others
He punished the man of God for the sign
He refused to acknowledge God's power
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam humbled himself and asked the man of God to pray for him
questions.explanation: When Jeroboam's hand withered, he asked the man of God to pray for its restoration (1 Kings 13:4, 6), showing humility and recognition of God's power through the prophet.

questions.question: How does the chapter teach about the importance of spiritual leadership and its impact on others?
options: Jeroboam made priests from the lowest people, leading to sin and destruction
Leadership is unimportant in spiritual matters
Anyone can be a spiritual leader without consequences
Spiritual leadership has no influence on the community
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam made priests from the lowest people, leading to sin and destruction
questions.explanation: Jeroboam consecrated unworthy priests (1 Kings 13:33), which became a sin to his house and led to its destruction (1 Kings 13:34), showing the grave responsibility of spiritual leadership.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 13 illustrate the importance of faithfulness in God's promises despite challenges?
options: The man of God’s initial obedience demonstrated faithfulness to God's Word
He abandoned God's command at the first challenge
Faithfulness is optional if others disagree
God's promises depend on human circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: The man of God’s initial obedience demonstrated faithfulness to God's Word
questions.explanation: The man of God initially obeyed by not returning the same way (1 Kings 13:10), showing faithfulness to God's command even when difficult. This models perseverance in obedience.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 13.

questions.question: What was the specific sign that the man of God from Judah gave to prove the word of the LORD regarding the altar in Bethel?
options: The altar would be split and ashes poured out
The altar would catch fire and burn to ashes
The altar would crumble to dust and blow away
The altar would be surrounded by fire and smoke
questions.correctAnswer: The altar would be split and ashes poured out
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 13:3 and 13:5, the man of God declares that the altar will be rent (split) and the ashes poured out, which happened exactly as he said.

questions.question: Why did the man of God refuse King Jeroboam's invitation to eat bread and drink water in Bethel?
options: He was commanded by the LORD not to eat or drink there
He was fasting for seven days
He was ritually unclean and could not eat with the king
He wanted to return immediately to Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He was commanded by the LORD not to eat or drink there
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:8-9 and 16-17 explain that the man of God was charged by the word of the LORD not to eat bread or drink water in that place or return by the same way he came.

questions.question: What was the old prophet's deception to bring the man of God back to his house?
options: He claimed an angel told him to bring the man of God back
He threatened to report him to King Jeroboam
He promised him riches and honor
He lied that the altar was repaired
questions.correctAnswer: He claimed an angel told him to bring the man of God back
questions.explanation: According to 1 Kings 13:18, the old prophet lied that an angel spoke to him commanding him to bring the man of God back to eat and drink with him.

questions.question: What was the consequence for the man of God after he disobeyed the LORD's command and ate bread in Bethel?
options: He was killed by a lion on the way back
He was imprisoned by King Jeroboam
He was struck with leprosy
He was exiled from Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He was killed by a lion on the way back
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 13:24, the man of God was slain by a lion as judgment for his disobedience in eating bread and drinking water as forbidden by the LORD.

questions.question: How did the lion behave after killing the man of God, according to the narrative?
options: It stood by the carcass and did not eat it
It ate the carcass and vanished
It roared loudly and ran away
It attacked the old prophet's ass
questions.correctAnswer: It stood by the carcass and did not eat it
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:24 and 13:28 describe that the lion stood beside the carcass and the ass but did not eat the carcass nor harm the ass, an unusual behavior signifying divine judgment.

questions.question: What did the old prophet command his sons to do after hearing about the lion and the carcass?
options: Saddle his ass so he could go and retrieve the carcass
Prepare a sacrifice to atone for the man of God
Report the event to King Jeroboam
Hide the carcass to prevent fear among the people
questions.correctAnswer: Saddle his ass so he could go and retrieve the carcass
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 13:27-29, the old prophet saddled his ass and went to bring back the man's body to bury him properly.

questions.question: What did the old prophet instruct his sons regarding his own burial after his death?
options: To bury him beside the man of God in the same sepulchre
To bury him in the city cemetery
To cremate his body as a sign of judgment
To scatter his ashes to the wind
questions.correctAnswer: To bury him beside the man of God in the same sepulchre
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:31 records the old prophet's command to be buried beside the man of God, indicating respect and acknowledgment of the prophecy's truth.

questions.question: According to the chapter, what was the prophetic significance of the man of God's initial prophecy against the altar in Bethel?
options: A child named Josiah from David's line would one day destroy the altar and priests there
The altar would become the center of worship for Israel
Jeroboam would be blessed for his altar
The altar would be rebuilt and sanctified
questions.correctAnswer: A child named Josiah from David's line would one day destroy the altar and priests there
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 13:2, the man of God prophesies that Josiah, a king from David's lineage, will destroy the altar and the priests who burn incense on it, a prophecy fulfilled generations later in 2 Kings 23.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the narrative structure of the man of God's obedience and disobedience in the chapter?
options: Chiastic structure emphasizing obedience and disobedience
Parallelism contrasting two kings
Allegory representing Israel's sin
An extended metaphor comparing altars to hearts
questions.correctAnswer: Chiastic structure emphasizing obedience and disobedience
questions.explanation: The chapter's narrative forms a chiasm where the man of God's initial obedience and proclamation of the word contrasts with his eventual disobedience and judgment (1 Kings 13:1-10 and 13:20-24).

questions.question: How does the behavior of the old prophet relate to the theme of false prophecy in the Hebrew Scriptures?
options: He lies claiming divine authority to deceive the man of God
He faithfully delivers the LORD's message without error
He refuses to speak to the king to avoid complicity
He condemns Jeroboam openly and is rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: He lies claiming divine authority to deceive the man of God
questions.explanation: The old prophet's false claim of an angelic message (1 Kings 13:18) illustrates the theme of false prophets who misuse divine authority, a recurring issue addressed in Deuteronomy 13 and Jeremiah.

questions.question: True or False: King Jeroboam repented and ceased his idolatrous practices after the prophecy of the man of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:33 states that Jeroboam did not turn from his evil way but continued to consecrate priests of the high places, indicating no repentance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Josiah' mentioned in the prophecy against the altar, in the context of Israel's history?
options: Josiah was a future king who reformed worship and destroyed idolatrous altars
Josiah was Jeroboam's son who continued his father's practices
Josiah was a foreign king who invaded Israel
Josiah was a priest who replaced the high priests
questions.correctAnswer: Josiah was a future king who reformed worship and destroyed idolatrous altars
questions.explanation: The prophecy in 1 Kings 13:2 foreshadows King Josiah's reforms in 2 Kings 23, where he destroyed the idolatrous altars and priests in Bethel and elsewhere.

questions.question: The drying up of King Jeroboam's hand when he stretched it out toward the man of God is an example of which type of biblical motif?
options: Divine judgment demonstrating power and authority
A ritual purification act
A symbolic blessing
A common illness of the time
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment demonstrating power and authority
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 13:4-6, Jeroboam's hand drying up is a sign of divine judgment confirming the truth of the prophecy and asserting God's authority over the king.

questions.question: In terms of intertextual connections, the command to not eat or drink in a certain place as given to the man of God parallels which other biblical narrative?
options: The Nazirite vow restrictions in Numbers 6
Elijah’s fasting on Mount Horeb in 1 Kings 19
The manna restriction in Exodus 16
Jesus' temptation in the wilderness in Matthew 4
questions.correctAnswer: The Nazirite vow restrictions in Numbers 6
questions.explanation: The specific restriction on eating and drinking recalls the Nazirite vow in Numbers 6, where abstinence is a sign of consecration and obedience to God’s command.

questions.question: What does the man of God's journey by a different route symbolize in the theological and literary context of the chapter?
options: Obedience to God's command to avoid places of idolatry
Avoiding confrontation with King Jeroboam
Hastening to deliver another prophecy
Returning to Judah to announce the king's death
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's command to avoid places of idolatry
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 13:10 emphasizes that the man of God was instructed not to return by the same way, symbolizing separation from idolatrous Bethel and obedience to divine instruction.

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What prophetic sign did the man of God give concerning the altar at Bethel?
options: The altar would be struck by lightning
The altar would be rent and ashes poured out
The altar would collapse completely
The altar would be consumed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: The altar would be rent and ashes poured out
questions.explanation: The man of God declared that the altar shall be rent and the ashes poured out as a sign from the LORD (1 Kings 13:3,5). This sign affirmed God's authority over false worship. Similar signs of God's judgment on idolatry are seen in Elijah's contest on Mount Carmel (1 Kings 18:38) and Jeremiah's prophecies against altars (Jeremiah 1:13-15).

questions.question: What happened to King Jeroboam's hand when he tried to seize the man of God?
options: It was healed instantly
It was paralyzed and could not be withdrawn
It was covered with scales
It was struck with fire
questions.correctAnswer: It was paralyzed and could not be withdrawn
questions.explanation: Jeroboam's hand dried up and he could not pull it back, demonstrating God's judgment on his opposition (1 Kings 13:4). This divine disabling recalls similar judgments in Scripture, such as Micaiah's prophecy against Ahab (1 Kings 22:24) and Paul's temporary blindness (Acts 9:3-9) as signs of divine authority.

questions.question: Why did the man of God refuse King Jeroboam's offer to reward him and come to his house?
options: He was afraid of the king
He was commanded by the LORD not to eat or drink there
He did not want to be honored
He planned to return the same way he came
questions.correctAnswer: He was commanded by the LORD not to eat or drink there
questions.explanation: The man of God said he was charged by the word of the LORD not to eat bread or drink water there nor return by the same way (1 Kings 13:8-9). This obedience reflects the biblical principle of submission to God's commands over human authority (Deuteronomy 13:4; Acts 5:29).

questions.question: What did the old prophet from Bethel claim that an angel told him?
options: To kill the man of God
To bring the man of God back to eat and drink with him
To let the man of God go in peace
To warn the king against the man of God
questions.correctAnswer: To bring the man of God back to eat and drink with him
questions.explanation: The old prophet lied, claiming an angel told him to bring the man of God back to eat and drink, contradicting the true word of the LORD (1 Kings 13:18). This highlights the danger of false prophecy and the necessity of discerning true revelation (Deuteronomy 18:20-22; Matthew 7:15-20).

questions.question: What was the consequence for the man of God when he disobeyed God's command?
options: He was imprisoned
He was slain by a lion
He was exiled
He was struck blind
questions.correctAnswer: He was slain by a lion
questions.explanation: Because he disobeyed the LORD's command, the man of God was killed by a lion, demonstrating God's holiness and judgment against disobedience (1 Kings 13:24). This echoes the seriousness of sin and God's justice seen throughout Scripture (Genesis 3:17-19; Romans 6:23).

questions.question: What did the lion do after it killed the man of God?
options: It ate the body
It guarded the body without eating it
It fled the scene
It roared loudly
questions.correctAnswer: It guarded the body without eating it
questions.explanation: The lion stood by the carcass and did not eat it, symbolizing God's control over even the agents of judgment (1 Kings 13:34, 13:28). This may signify the sanctity of the man of God even in judgment, reflecting God's sovereignty (Psalm 22:21; Daniel 6:22).

questions.question: How did the old prophet respond upon finding the man of God's body?
options: He ignored it
He buried it and mourned
He left it in the road
He burned it
questions.correctAnswer: He buried it and mourned
questions.explanation: The old prophet took up the carcass, buried it in his own grave, and mourned, showing respect for God's prophet despite his disobedience (1 Kings 13:29-30). This act reflects the biblical practice of honoring God's servants (Genesis 50:2-3; 2 Samuel 1:17-27).

questions.question: What did the old prophet instruct his sons regarding his burial?
options: To bury him at the city gate
To bury him beside the man of God
To bury him in the wilderness
To scatter his ashes
questions.correctAnswer: To bury him beside the man of God
questions.explanation: He told his sons to bury him in the same sepulchre as the man of God, indicating honor and recognition of the prophecy's truth (1 Kings 13:31). This symbolizes unity in God's prophetic word and is consistent with honoring God's messengers (Luke 7:16; Hebrews 11:4).

questions.question: What did the man of God prophesy about the future king Josiah?
options: He would build a temple in Bethel
He would offer priests of high places upon the altar
He would conquer all Israel
He would reign peacefully forever
questions.correctAnswer: He would offer priests of high places upon the altar
questions.explanation: The man of God prophesied Josiah by name, stating he would offer priests of high places upon the altar and burn men's bones there (1 Kings 13:2). This messianic prophecy links to Josiah's later reforms (2 Kings 23) and God's judgment on idolatry, affirming divine sovereignty and covenant fulfillment (Psalm 89:3-4, Romans 15:12).

questions.question: How did Jeroboam respond after hearing the man of God's prophecy and sign?
options: He repented and destroyed the altar
He continued his idolatry and made priests of the lowliest people
He imprisoned the man of God
He sought counsel from other prophets
questions.correctAnswer: He continued his idolatry and made priests of the lowliest people
questions.explanation: Jeroboam did not repent but consecrated the lowest of the people as priests, persisting in sin and idolatry (1 Kings 13:33). This reflects human rebellion against God's call and the consequences of hardened hearts (Romans 1:18-32; Hebrews 3:12-19).

questions.question: What theological truth does the disobedience and punishment of the man of God illustrate?
options: God always rewards disobedience
God's commands must be obeyed exactly, regardless of circumstances
Prophets may choose which commands to follow
God is indifferent to sin in His servants
questions.correctAnswer: God's commands must be obeyed exactly, regardless of circumstances
questions.explanation: The man of God's death for disobedience shows God's holiness and demand for exact obedience (1 Kings 13:21-22). This affirms the doctrine of God's justice and the seriousness of sin (Exodus 20:5; James 2:10; Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What does the interaction between the man of God and the old prophet reveal about discerning true prophecy?
options: All prophets are equally inspired
Prophetic words must be tested against God's prior revelation
Prophets can change God's commands
Prophecy is always literal
questions.correctAnswer: Prophetic words must be tested against God's prior revelation
questions.explanation: The old prophet lied about an angel's message, leading to the man of God's disobedience, highlighting the necessity to test prophecy by Scripture (1 Kings 13:18). This principle is affirmed in Deuteronomy 18:20-22 and 1 John 4:1.

questions.question: What attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated by the events in this chapter?
options: God's mercy to sinners
God's holiness and justice
God's indifference to idolatry
God's unpredictability
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness and justice
questions.explanation: God's judgment on Jeroboam, the man of God, and false prophecy reveals His holiness and justice (1 Kings 13:21-24, 34). This aligns with biblical teaching on God's righteous nature (Isaiah 6:3; Romans 3:25-26; Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: What is the eschatological significance of the prophecy against the altar in Bethel?
options: It predicts the eternal destruction of idolatry
It promises the building of a new temple
It foretells peace between Israel and Judah
It describes the end of the monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: It predicts the eternal destruction of idolatry
questions.explanation: The prophecy that men's bones would be burned on the altar symbolizes God's ultimate judgment on idolatry (1 Kings 13:2, 32-34). This points forward to New Testament teachings on final judgment and the establishment of true worship (Revelation 21:8; 1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: How does this chapter contribute to our understanding of human sinfulness and divine judgment?
options: Sin has no consequences if repented
Disobedience to God leads to severe judgment even for His servants
God overlooks small sins
Judgment is delayed indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience to God leads to severe judgment even for His servants
questions.explanation: The death of the disobedient prophet shows that sin and rebellion have serious consequences, emphasizing human responsibility before God (1 Kings 13:21-24). This is consistent with Romans 3:23 and Hebrews 10:26-31.

questions.question: What does the man of God's mission to Bethel teach about God's sovereignty over false worship?
options: False worship is tolerated by God
God sends prophets to confront and judge idolatry
Idolatry is acceptable if done in Israel
God ignores altars that are not in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: God sends prophets to confront and judge idolatry
questions.explanation: The sending of the man of God to denounce the altar shows God's active judgment against idolatry (1 Kings 13:1-2). This is consistent with prophets like Elijah and Jeremiah confronting false worship (Jeremiah 7:9-11; Ezekiel 8:6-18).
